prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author of the situation is in the wrong for telling their friend that her single status is due to having five kids by different fathers. 

First, I need to consider the context. The friend has been making hurtful comments to the author for two years, including body-shaming and questioning her dating life. The author has tried to brush off these insults but finally responded by pointing out the friend's situation as the reason she's single. The friend then reacted angrily and hung up.

Now, the main issue is whether the author's response was appropriate. On one hand, the friend's comments were clearly insulting and targeted the author's weight, job, and dating life. The author might have felt justified in pointing out the friend's own issues. But on the other hand, even if the friend was being insulting, the author's response was a direct accusation about the friend's personal life, which could be seen as crossing a line.

The friends' mutual friends are now criticizing the author for having "skinny privilege" and being entitled. The author argues that they work hard and aren't privileged. However, the key point here is whether the author's response was a valid way to handle the situation. 

In terms of friendship dynamics, it's generally not helpful to call out someone's personal choices, even if they are problematic, especially after they've been making hurtful comments. The author might have been justified in feeling frustrated, but the way they addressed it could have been more constructive. Instead of making a direct accusation, maybe suggesting support or understanding would have been better. 

Also, the author's friend's behavior was toxic, but the author's response might have been too harsh and could have been seen as judgmental. Even if the statement is true, it's possible that the delivery was unkind and contributed to the fallout. 

Considering all this, the author might be in the wrong because while the friend was being rude, responding with an accusation about her personal life might not be the right approach. There might have been a better way to handle the situation without alienating the friend and mutual friends. The answer might lean towards A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because the response was a direct personal attack, even if the friend was being difficult.
